comments.commentBody: I'm trying hard to not get caught up in the red vs. blue battle that seems to be raging in our country, which I see as mostly a ploy of the rich elite to distract us from the fact that they are robbing us blind. However, I don't see the electoral college issue as a red vs blue affair-it's really more a matter of basic fairness, and this article does a nice job of addressing this matter. Getting rid of the electoral college is something that should have been done long ago, but is especially important now given voting demographics, which seem increasingly likely to result in a Republican president-elect with only a minority of the popular vote. Unfortunately, probably the only way this can happen is if we can get enough states to join the National Popular Vote interstate compact. The states with outsized voting power (e.g., Wyoming) will never agree to give up this power, and the beneficiaries of the electoral college voting system (Republicans) will also never go along with this, so a constitutional amendment is never going to work. Are there still enough blue states to make the National Popular Vote interstate compact relevant? Are republicans now so much in control that they can effectively ensure this is a non-issue?
"The rich elite" are exploiting the dumbbells of this country, who don't have a clue their being exploited. So what's your point?

If you do not like this law then change the Constitution. This is also true with first amendment free speech, second amendment gun rights and all of the Bill of Rights. It is absolutely improper to abridge these rights through twisted legal interpretation and a myriad of laws that effectively abridge these basic American rights.
More accurately, abridging free speech rights while expanding gun rights beyond the imaginations of the Founders.

Yes we should all play nice; no grabbing the ladies without permission, no
Using the Tweet machine to name call, no going to bed with corporations---they're bad lovers. Finally, never do anything to inform yourself about major international conflicts---information only messes with those good gut instincts
that let you know more than the Generals.

There is a new boss on the world stage and (forgive me) the new boss ain't the same as the old boss.

Do you think that parts of the US Constitution which failed to recognize basic human rights of blacks, women and Native Americans was "right" and just? Do you think that application of the US Constitution to  automatic weapons is the nature of its original intent? It has been changed before. Time to change it again.

Functionally for the movie plot, that's still magic, or deus ex machine, if you prefer.

I really like a lot of the movie, but the military stuff (especially the secret placement of the bomb) was not interesting, and in the case of the bomb didn't even make sense (what exactly was that supposed to accomplish, and wouldn't the military have completely blocked off access to the ship after placing it?)
The need for suspension of disbelief is not that great for a movie that wants to be quite deep. It was beautiful, but I found it a bit hollow.

Actually, Robert, undocumented people are not here "illegally," as it is not a federal crime to be in the US in violation of federal immigration laws. Congress considered making undocumented presence in the US a felony in 2005, but declined to do so. Instead, undocumented presence is a civil matter that can lead to deportation through proceedings before immigration courts. The problem is that, through indefinite detention, we have created a de facto system of criminal punishment (without any of the Constitutional protections we provide in actual criminal contexts) for civil matters that often do not end up leading to deportation. Such a system is clearly unjust.

About 2/3rds of the undocumented immigrants in the US entered legally and, therefore, have not committed any crime. The other 1/3 entered illegally, but under federal law, doing so is only a misdemeanor unless they had been previously deported or removed from the US and then came back illegally (in which case, they can receive up to 2 years in prison).

So, in the large majority of cases, the rhetoric about "illegal" immigrants is entirely false. In most other cases, it is vastly overstated, as we typically do not consider committing a misdemeanor some massive issue.

Do we need to improve the immigration system in the US? Certainly. But scapegoating people with false and overwrought claims of criminal behavior is a horrible way to do so.

https://www.facebook.com/WinningProgressive/

I had no expectations of action it all. Still didn't find it all that life-altering. The military stuff with the Chinese, as well as the secret bombing (that apparently no one was upset about, even though it could have killed the scientists and also ruined earth) were just silly.
And the main meditation on time and life was not that explored all that deeply, though at least interesting.
Is she the only person who now can perceive time that way? Or did all humans learn this, once she solved the language? (In which case Ian should have known this about his kid too).

" This is sci-fi for grown-ups" - that's fairly condescending towards those who didn't like it.
One can be grown-up (and enjoy thoughtful sci-fi) and still have a very different reaction to the movie than you did. I felt that it barely raises the questions of time and humanity, and certainly didn't think it meditated on them.

It's a review, an opinion.   Take it as such and no more or less.  If you want glowing reviews just read the ads where every movie poster of every movie  screams about best actor, picture of the yesr, and other oscar blah blah blah.
Thanks for saying this.  I wholeheartedly agree with every word. I'm starting to think that these critics never even watch the movie.

First of all, all of the negative reviews of this film are coming from people who never actually saw the film.  If you read what their review, you can tell that they've only seen the trailer at best.  I can't understand why this movie is getting so much bad press.  I watched it this weekend and I absolutely loved it.  The jokes were funny.  The emotional parts were definitely heart felt and authentic.  The acting was amazing. And the script was one of the best I've seen this year.  Just for perspective, I went to see Star Wars: Rouge One the night before I watched this.  Collateral Beauty is much more entertaining.  I actually wanted to see it again once I left the theater.  Star Wars on the other hand almost put me to sleep.  Mind you, I'm a huge Star Wars fan.  I've never seen such an aggressive attempt to sabotage a film before in my life.  Every major publication trashed this film.  Meanwhile, every review about Star Wars: Rogue One has been nothing less than a celebration.  Fact is, Rogue One has more characters than a Donald Trump tweet.  The script has very few emotions and lacks any sense of urgency.  Pay no attention these reviews.   Go see Collateral Beauty for yourself.  You be the judge.

Most of us have known the premise of this flick for at least a year.  You totally missed the point.  What they have done is make the first half of the original Star Wars.  I had to come right home and watch that movie.  For maybe the 50th time since '77.  They fit perfectly together.
Boy, if that wasn't a spoiler... thanks a lot.
Christine, what on earth are you talking about?

I completely agree with Scott. Rogue One falls into troublesome story elements that MMORPGs have been using for over a decade that involve tasks and quests. No character development and no substance. Disappointing because of the great talent in the movies and the lack of their use by the creators is a shame. So many aspects of this film just felt a little off... exactly like Liz Lemon's Peppy Bismilk. Loved Donnie Yen though.

We saw the film tonight. Less than stellar sound dampened the experience, with some dialogue impossible to understand. This review makes me want to see it again. Extremely well written and insightful review.

There's not a moment in the movie, contra our critic's comment, that Lee Chandler is ever "half-convinced" he wasn't responsible for the horrific tragedy at the movie's core. There's plenty of class+gender subtext here -- some of it subtly portraying white advantage, much of it showing the wounds of class. Very well acted, well-written and with an unexpected turn in the corner, a wrenching scene near the end that is devastating+oddly not even hinted at in the review. Also, to call the kid's loss of his father at 16 and left w/o a parent at home, is not "manageable."
I like DeBuyer steel crepe pans - just big enough for two fillets - I keep a couple for this purpose. Steel gets really hot and makes a nice crust & steel is much lighter than cast iron.
I thought it was going to be on the bland side, so I chopped and sauteed an onion and 3 garlic cloves and added that to the spinach.
Definitely the right move. These are a given in my vegetarian lasagna, along with mushrooms and red peppers. My carnivore relations love it.
If you have a good, robust sauce, you don't need to do this.

I agree with you on the flavorful additions. But I always use fresh baby spinach (washed), and it wilts perfectly while the lasagna bakes. I'm sure that preserves the precious nutrients. The addition of sliced mushrooms would also make this a great lasagna.
Simply fantastic!
Yum. Very different from any ive ever had!

This has a more interesting flavor than some carrot-based soups I have made.  I doubled the cumin/turmeric/coriander and used 1.75 cups (1 standard size can) of chicken broth and made up the missing 0.25 cup with coconut milk.  This is special enough to serve to dinner guests.

I made this for the first time tonight. So delicious!  I love the zing of freshly cracked black pepper.  The only thing I did differently was to add thinly sliced ripened pears post bake, some arugula, and a few splashes of sherry vinegar for some sweetness/acidity.  Very good!

Easy to make, big hit with everyone who tried them. Just made another batch today for gifting purposes. I too tempered more chocolate than the recipe called for, and used what was left to make some ersatz peppermint bark. Also at least for my oven I need to start watching them closely at the 13-14 minute mark so they don't burn.
It's delicious. I cook it almost every week in the winter, sometimes adding additional garlic in the puree or using stock instead of water.  It's a great post-workout recovery meal.

I have made these cookies many many times and the flours DO make a difference. Using the cake flour and bread flour make for a more "melt in your mouth" cookie.  Also don't forget to chill the dough for at least 24 hours with 36 hours being better. I give these cookies each year and they are always a big hit with people begging me for the recipe. One last thing I use Ghirardelli Chocolate Baking Chips, Bittersweet Chocolate 60%
Worth the fuss. I've tried all the options for making it easier bc I am lazy. I am no cook, but everyone around here knows my cookies (this recipe) are the bomb.
